item.title: [ML Basics] Probability and Information Theory
item.description: Random Variables A random variable is a variable that can take on different values randomly. We typically denote the random variable itself with a lower case letter in plain typeface, and the values it can take on with lower case script letters. For example, $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ are both possible values that the random variable $x$ can take on. For vector-valued variables, we would write the random variable as $\mathrm{x}$ and one of its values as $x$.
